content.description: Another worthy link up. Climb The Pit to the second to last bolt before the chains. Diagonal left for a few more bolts of technical pocket pulling, and finish on the nice orange stone that shares its finish with The JJ Memorial route. The highest anchors on the left side of the wall, above the Crazy Train anchors, are your finishing target.
content.protection: Bolts... about 7... lower off the chains. Stick clip the high first bolt.
content.location: Climbs out the middle of the low Dry wall cave, sharing the start with The Pit. Heads left from the second to last bolt of The Pit and clips a few more bolts until the highest set of anchors on the left side of the wall. This is the same finish as The JJ Memorial route.

content.description: This is the link up of Graffiti Patient and Way Hammered.  At the top of Graffiti Patient, traverse right through ever worstening holds past one bolt into the upper slab crux of Way Hammered and finish on that route.  The first assentionest thought this felt like about 5.12d, My partner and I felt like it is a bit harder than that due to making a lot of moves on pretty terrible holds with no rests between the Graffiti Patient anchors and the last bolt of Way Hammered, so I put it in as 5.13a, but with the right beta it may be only 5.12d.
content.protection: Bolts (permadraws except the one traverse bolt) to anchors with steel lowering biners.
content.location: Start on Graffiti patient, head right at the anchors and finish up on Way Hammered.

content.description: the crux is either between the 3rd and 4th bolts or at the 6th.
content.location: route E in the photo topo.

content.description: long moves off of positive holds, pumpy.
content.location: G on photo topo

content.description: Starts on the right side of wall, really fun warmup.
content.location: left side of wall

content.description: Fun climb with delicate moves.
content.location: Walk up the hill to the far right side of the wall. This is the fifth bolted line after the little grove of trees and bushes.

content.description:
A good long route on semi-solid rock.

Steep and sustained,

Pocket Full of Trundles

starts on small, positive holds and a cool flake. The climbing quickly turns tricky, and surprises you with powerful crux. Find a nice rest around bolt two then continue on up about 15 feet to the route's redpoint crux just below a large positive pocket. Small deceiving holds through a mini bulge wear the weary climber out, keep truckin' to a decent rest or two then finish direct on the steep, pumpy face.

Long and continuous

Pocket Full of Trundles

is a trademark route and the second best warm-up for the area.
content.location:
This is the second route in from the right side of the main face. Its just left of

Something Must Break

and just right of

Stop That Train

content.description: Another good, short, bouldery route. The crux is encountered between the 2nd and 3rd bolts. The starting pocket moves pulling out of the cave also require a motivated tugger.
content.protection: Bolts. Best to stick clip the first bolt. Lower of chains at about 30 feet.
content.location: This route starts on the shelf and climbs pockets out the steepest, deepest part of the low cave.

content.description: Start as for The Pit, but instead of clipping the chains keep moving right. Clip one anchor bolt of Graffiti Patient and move past the Way Patient bolt, through a crux and finish on Way Hammered.
content.location: Start as for The Pit and end on Way Hammered.

content.description: As you climb, it meanders slightly left and the harder moves are near clip 2. The whole route is about 20m in total. Although it is pretty much all cobblestone, it may be identified by a small section of sandstone in the lower-middle portion of the route.
content.location:
The third route after the little grove of trees.

Belay begins on the trail to the right of all of "Something Must Break".

content.description: A new route that needs to be cleaned-up with more ascents.
content.location: This route is the left of the two routes that sit seperatley up the hill and left of the Dry Wall's low cave. Some ass clown "Frank" wrote his name on the wall twice in this area. This route climbs by the left silvery bluish Frank graffiti- If you know the original name, please speak up.

content.description: Fun route. Scramble up slabs to short bulging wall. Dyno then fun pocket pulling.
content.location: Far right side of the wall. This is the sixth route to the right of the small grove of trees and bushes.

content.description: This route is new so its cleaning up. High first clip leads to a wonderful sequential play around the middle. Super fun.
content.location: Between the 11a and 10c/d. The first route after the little grove of trees.

content.description:
It looks like this one is missing from the line-up on MP.

This climb starts out of the pit on a large lay-backish hold.  Requires burly pulling and a heel-toe gimmick may help in this section. After the roof section, the head wall has some smaller crimps/feet.
content.location: Starts on the left side of the pit

content.description: Another new route that needs some more ascents before its quality can be determined.
content.protection: Bolts. Shares anchors with Left be Frank.
content.location: The rightmost of the two routes up-hill and right from the low Dry wall cave. Climbs above the black "Frank" graffiti.

content.description: This route climbs Graffiti Patient buts heads right after the anchors to traverse past a bolt into Way Hammered, another bolt between Way Hammered and Grushenka, through Grushenka, into the crux of Stop That Terrain and finishes on those anchors. Since this route traverse through several areas that don't see much traffic, it is recommended that belayers wear helmets. Finally, I don't know if someone else did this climb before me, but I can't find it in the guidebook nor on here at all. I suggest the grade at 5.13a, but am open to discussion based on what others have to say who have done it.

Easy, fun, left trending climbing at the start leads straight up through a right facing type feature to a very bouldery crux (V6) around and above the second bolt. Climb straight up through the crux to the horizontal break- up higher you will eventually move left past the rounded arete and into the left facing corner feature. Finish the route by exiting out the right side of the big roof and clipping the chains above. Expect shallow two finger pockets with cranker moves at the crux and a bit of pump management above.
content.location: Sixth route from the left. Start by traversing left from the ground up to the first bolt by the sand-lense huecos.

content.description: the first route to the right of the little bouldering cave. one of the shorter routes and one of the best to do in the rain. the start is tricky and most people use cheater stones, I dont think it changes the grade. the route is characterized by two big moves off small holds into pockets next to the 3rd and 4th bolts.
content.protection: 5 bolts. top 3 or 4 + anchors usually have hanging draws.
content.location: first route right of bouldering cave.

content.description: one of the shorter routes
content.location: first route on the left on the main wall. Route A in the photo topo

content.description: Typical Echo cobbles and edges lead to a steeper mid section where you will find the crux.  Sure, it's a nice warm up, but it's also just fun climbing on slightly more vertical rock than the neighbors to the left.   Named after the train conductors who like to blow their horns right while you are at the crux.
content.location: On the right side of the Dry Wall where it is less steep. The second route right of the little grove of trees and bushes.   The first several bolts are glue-ins which should help identifying it.  5 of the bolts were swapped out for glue-ins in 2019 to better align the bolts with the climbing.   The route "Kevin's 11" is very close on the left at the start before diverging about 15' up.

content.description:
A long, technical face route with an early crux. Start with some tweaky, tense climbing to a high-ish first bolt. The climbing eases up after bolt two with a red point crux lurking up high...

Fairly quality rock given the nature of the area, this line is worth doing if you're pumped and still looking to climb.
content.protection: Six bolts to a shared anchor.
content.location:
Right of

Something Must Break

this route is found on the far right side of

The Dry Wall

. Follow a faint trail through the scrub to a small opening. This route is the fourth bolted route to the right of the small grove of trees and bushes.
